If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would consider this game to be a repeated version of the famous Prisoner's Dilemma, where the payoff matrix is slightly modified. In a one-time Prisoner's Dilemma, cooperating (picking R) results in a better outcome for both players if they both cooperate, but defecting (picking B) guarantees a better outcome for the defector, no matter what the other player does.

However, in this game, choosing B always gives a lower payoff than choosing R, except when the opponent also chooses B. But since we don't know the strategy of our anonymous opponent, it's hard to make an informed decision based on a single round.

When the game is repeated multiple times, as in this case with 75 rounds, things change significantly due to concepts like tit-for-tat and cooperation, especially when considering long-term payoffs. A strategy like tit-for-tat (start by cooperating, then do what your opponent did last time) would work well in this game.

That being said, there's no guarantee that my opponent will use the same strategy or any predictable pattern. So, it's still a risk to choose R every time because I might end up with nothing if my opponent defects (picks B). But, in the long run, I would expect better payoffs by choosing R more often than B, as it yields higher returns when both players cooperate.

Given these considerations, I would choose to play R (cooperate) for most of the rounds and occasionally switch to B (defect) to avoid being too predictable. Therefore, my choice would be {R}.

However, keep in mind that my choice may not be optimal if my opponent consistently defects or chooses an entirely different strategy. This reasoning assumes a rational player on both sides and repeated interactions. In real-life situations, players might not always make the most logical choices, so the outcome could vary significantly.
